_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Lake Pleasant Water Treatment Plant (WTP) located at 37000 N. New River Road in Peoria, Arizona is a conventional water treatment plant that treats Central Arizona Project (CAP) canal water to potable use. The facility is operated by Veolia North America under contract to the City of Phoenix. The WTP contains a covered process subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), 29 CFR 1910.119, and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program Rule (RMP), 40 CFR 68.



The covered process at the WTP is chlorine (CAS# 7782-50-5), which is injected into the finished water for disinfection. The chlorine storage and feed system are designed to utilize one-ton chlorine containers within a fully contained building dedicated for the purpose. The chlorine system is designed to provide continuous finished water chlorine residual. The facility was initially constructed under a design, build, operate (DBO) project with Black & Veatch/McCarthy as the design team and American Water Enterprises as the Operator and the facility was commissioned in June 2007.

 

The facility operator has implemented Process Safety Management/Risk Management (PSM/RMP) procedures to prevent the accidental release of chlorine and to mitigate consequences should a release occur. The program follows the elements of the PSM standard. The process hazard analysis (PHA) of the covered process was most recently revalidated in June 2021 and the PSM/RMP program was most recently audited in April 2019; both of these activities were led by qualified third-party PSM consultants.



The WTP contains up to 20,000 pounds of chlorine, with 10,000 pounds "in use." The chlorine feed system consists of five, one-ton containers (tonners) "on-line" and five tonners placed in "stand-by" (upon change out of the bank of containers that have been depleted). Chlorine containers are stored in an enclosed building that is designed to contain a wor

st-case chlorine gas release and the chlorine building is provided with an emergency scrubber that is designed to treat 2,000 pounds of chlorine gas. 



Chlorine leak detectors located in the chlorine building activate alarms (horns and beacons), the building containment controls, and the emergency chlorine scrubber upon detection of chlorine at established setpoints. The facility is a non-responding facility and coordinates emergency response with the City of Phoenix Fire Department. The facility maintains an Emergency Kit "B" for use by external emergency responders to containing major leaks on the chlorine containers; this kit contains devices and tools to contain leaks in and around container valves or in the side wall of a container.



The emergency chlorine scrubber can also be manually activated via local controls at the scrubber and the chlorine supply can be remotely shutdown (at the containers) via a manual emergency shutdown button located immediately outside of the main chlorine building entrance.



The WTP is staffed 24 hours/day by a licensed Water Treatment Operator. The Operator controls the chlorine system from the Operator Control Room located within the Administrative/Operations Building. The chlorine building is a secured zone within a secured site, and all access doors to the chlorine building are secured with access controls. A two-person rule applies for all work within the chlorine building. 



This is a non-responding facility and Veolia North America has implemented an Emergency Action Pan that addresses evacuation and in the event of a chlorine emergency, notification of the Fire Department will be notified. The facility maintains a "B" kit for use by the Fire Department Hazmat Unit to contain major leaks on the containers.  The facility has not experienced any chlorine incidents in the previous five-years.
